title: Thursday, 5th July, 2018
bodyHTML:
AAAA bonjour les amis !
Pseudonym *tap* *tap* Is this thing on?
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Hi. Good morning. Hello.

BornCynic Morning
VV75 morning
Blank canvas good morning everyone
SupposeToBeWorking... morning
BE11:10am

Sorry, late start, because I'm trying to do 15 things at once.

Pseudonym Ooh look! If you wait around long enough it starts up on the left too!
BE11:10am

Markets Live is only #12 on that list. Apologies for not prioritising you, ROTR.

BornCynic BE - it is always a late start. No need to apologise...............
pancakes or waffles Better than #13 but would've been nice to be #11
11:10 am
BE11:10am

So .............. where do we begin?

Tom Dalgleish BE we do understand. A one legged kick as the Singaporeans say
BE11:11am

I'm thinking we might begin here.

BornCynic PM has given up on us BE - is it you next?
Soundbuy Morning..........
BE11:11am

Are we there yet You need to go on a course
11:12 am
BE11:12am

At current prices that's about £2.4m to the CEO.

Swedish Chef Good morning. Anybody want to buy one of my football shirts?
BE11:12am

Current prices being .....

Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 511.50, down 104 (-16.90%), High: 516.50, Low: 431.00, Volume: 5.82m
11:12 am
BE11:12am

You remember Sophos, right?

BE11:13am

Security software, odd preferred definition of profit, cracking billings growth when it floated in 2015.

BE11:14am

What's happened, as per Q1, is that billings growth isn't.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Hit just 2% at constant currency.

BE11:14am

Which the company blames on tough YOY

BE11:15am

And last year's ransomware stuff, which led a lot of people to buy Endpoint.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

(Endpoint's the thing that runs in the background of corporate computers and kills JavaScript Bitcoin miners trying to hijack your system. We use it here.)

Grouchmonkey Yo
BE11:16am

Anyway ..... the company's excuse seems fair enough. But also ......

BE11:17am

...... it comes a couple of weeks after share awards that are at least partly on Q4 delivery.

vonB @swedish chef - short of supporters?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

So. This rapid slowdown .... might it suggest a rush towards hitting numbers in Q4 rather than having a pipeline of deals for Q1?

Grouchmonkey I run Mac OSX and know nothing about software - can any of you tech types tell me if I need any sort of endpoint equivalent?
BE11:18am

Here's Neil Campling, now of Mirabaud.

BE11:18am

Disappointing Q1 - billings growth of 6%, or just 2% at CC. Company had only reaffirmed FY mid teen YoY billings growth for FY in mid-June at investor conferences. Enduser growth had been particularly strong in FY18 (30% CC growth in FY18) so the reference to Enduser being particularly weak is disappointing, regardless of facing tough comps. We'd also been expecting some tailwind from GDPR implementation which hasn't come through. Sophos sales execution is becoming more volatile and the statement reads that Q2 may also be tough as returning to mid-teens billings won't be until H2 FY19. Stock is up 47% from April lows when we thought the company would have a better than expected end to FY18. They did. But this hasn't continued in Q1. The sales execution is now becoming more volatile and management’s ability to manage expectations will be called into question. Current consensus has 17% sales growth for FY19, which is now a pipe dream given the awful start to the year in billings growth and no recovery in billings is seen until H2 19. Q1 billings 6%, say Q2 is 10%, and H2 15% then you have 10-12% for FY19. Which translates into c.35% cut to consensus sales forecasts for FY19. Just not good enough.

Swedish Chef Buying em in London, selling in Glasgow. I believe it’s called arbitrage in these ere columns
rw42 @Grouch, depends whether you use adblockers and how dodgy the websites you visit are.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

I should note that sellside, mostly, are still buying.

BE11:20am

Stifel takes comfort in the "long term outlook remains unchanged" stuff.

BE11:21am

Sophos indicates that the malaise lasts into Q2 – which to be fair, we had expected. Positively, the H2 and beyond, guidance is unchanged. Whilst this is disappointing, in truth Q1 and Q2 have tough comps from last year which was the height of Wannacry crisis. But for us there are other issues which also ‘muddy the waters’ – for example we are unsure if GDRP and those new Sophos EndPoint products, may have pulled forward spend into Q4/2018A. Also, Sophos is trying to change buyer behaviour from a ‘point product’ market to a product suite approach – a lofty goal and we do not know if it has created sales execution wrinkles in the short term. Net/net we are still fanboys. The negative share price reaction is a great opportunity to pick up shares ‘on the cheap’, but we think that the mainstay of investors will await further disclosure, 26 July, and so we expect the shares to remain soggy in the short term. To reflect our forecast changes (i.e. Q1 bookings from 12% to 6% and FY/2019E Adj EBITDA from US$58.8m to US$49.2m) and the knock on effect through FY2019E, we have reduced our target price to 637p (from 712p). Whilst we acknowledge the short-term challenge, we retain our Buy.

Grouchmonkey No dodgy websites, no adblockers on the desktop, though I do use them for mobile apps
Tom Dalgleish Could virus detection be recession proof? Idle hands?
11:21 am
BE11:21am

As you probably guessed from "Net/net we are still fanboys", that's George O'Connor. Ex Panmure.

Pseudonym Presumably Sophos sells a lot in foreign so numbers got hit badly by Brexit.
BE11:23am

And Jefferies.

BE11:23am

The 1Q19 trading update indicates that Sophos is still navigating the tough comparatives from the boost in previous periods from global ransomware attacks (eg. WannaCry and Petya). However, as seen with 3Q18, it is challenging to draw conclusions on long-term growth trends from a single quarter. Furthermore, 1Q is seasonally the smallest quarter typically accounting for c.20% of the FY billings. Comps become easier from 2H onwards underpinning company's guidance. Nevertheless, at first glance, we believe consensus billings and uFCF are likely to reduce by 4-5% and 5-6% respectively.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

... I .... think ................ that RAW disclaimer was triggered by "draw"?

Soundbuy 'draw conclusions' throwing up RAW.............
hedgehog purplebricks ..?
BE11:25am

Though the RAW disclaimer won't show up in the post-show transcript, so that'll make no sense post hoc.

undefined
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Okay, so Glencore.

littleclenches stand down everyone
Grouchmonkey ABF?
BE11:26am

You remember Glencore! You'll remember in August 2014, it launched a $1bn share buyback.

BE11:27am

Then in September 2015 it launched a rescue rights issue.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

And now in July 2018 it's launching a $1bn share buyback.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 329.80, up 10.35 (+3.24%), High: 334.60, Low: 321.45, Volume: 24.51m
BE11:28am

The theme here is that management's much more confident about the DOJ and the DRC than investors.

Anthony Marinos hey
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Ivan's signalling confidence by chucking some money out.

BE11:29am

However, it's not entirely clear why anyone should trust Glencore management's confidence. Its record speaks for itself.

Dec69 - Skeptic a bitter sweet pill @ABF
BE11:30am

However ........ we have a small rally off a ten or 11 month low. So I guess it's done the trick short term.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Here's Caz.

BE11:31am

On yesterday’s close and using spot prices, the buyback is equivalent to an increase in 2018E shareholder returns of ~1.6%, from 6.0% to 7.6%, which compares favourably to BHP & RIO’s div yield of ~6.6%. Balance sheet implications aren’t onerous, in our opinion, highlighted by pro-forma YE’18 spot ND/EBITDA increasing modestly to 0.2x vs. 0.1x previously. Furthermore, we expect there is potentially upside to incremental returns going forward, given: (i) we forecast spot 2018E FCF at ~15% and management have previously said they could return FCF in the absence of “other deployment opportunities”; (ii) pro-forma YE’18 net debt (ex RMI) on spot is ~US$3.5bn (post buyback) which compares to GLEN’s target US$10-16bn net debt range, which is equivalent to a capital surplus of 11-21%; and (iii) GLEN is experiencing strong earnings tailwinds from key commodities such as thermal coal. After the recent share price performance (-15% since end-June), GLEN trades on 4.8x/4.0x spot EV/EBITDA 2018/19E and 15%/18% FCF yields. We remain OW, and we identify today’s news as a potential catalyst for sharpening markets’ focus on GLEN’s potential returns upside vs. valuation metrics. But, for a sustained re-rating in the equity we believe the market needs clarity on unresolved geopolitical & governance risks, acutely highlighted recently by the subpoena from the US DOJ.

A. M. @Grouchmonkey: sophos offers a free OSX antivirus. If you want to be a bit more watchful, try 'Little Snitch' (firewall).
BE11:32am

Note, BTW, that $1bn is only 1.5% or so of the market cap.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Or five days volume.

Anthony Marinos Morning folks, how are we doing?
BE11:33am

It's purely a signal. It's virtue signalling.

undefined
Grouchmonkey Thanks @AM
11:34 am
BE11:35am

Operational note: new commenters get their first few messages placed in quarantine automatically.

BE11:36am

For checking by the moderation team. You need to earn the right to comment, and you do that with a clean comment history.

BE11:36am

If you're wondering why your comments are stuck in "pending", that's why.

11:36 am
undefined
BE11:36am

Okay ..... what next? AB Foods mentioned.

Associated British Foods plc (ABF:LSE): Last: 2,597, down 120 (-4.42%), High: 2,660, Low: 2,562, Volume: 999.73k
hornblower any PURP comment?
11:36 am
BE11:37am

There are two parts here. The explicit warning and the buried one.

BE11:37am

First, there's sugar. EU pricing pressures mean sugar profitability's been guided down again.

BE11:38am

Which isn't a total surprise and doesn't tend to affect AB that much, because no one really cares that much about groceries.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

The second bit is, of course, Primark.

BE11:38am

And the news there is mixed. On the positive side, like-for-like sales are improving.

BE11:39am

On the negative side, absolute sales are not because space expansion's been slower than expected.

Groundhog Day @BE: Have you heard anything re inmarsat? Deafening silence. But usually would not have expected this silence if the deal were off already. Ie still seems plausible no agreement on price, but smells like Echostar would make a bid to keep deal alive at the very least, even if the price would then still move to get mgmt approval. Only my thoughts. What do you think?
11:39 am
BE11:40am

So .... if you're in AB Foods for the Primark expansion story, there are reasons to be a bit wary this morning.

BE11:40am

Geoff Ruddell at Morgan Stanley says:

BE11:41am

The key 'good news' here is that margins at Primark are now expected to be 'well ahead' of last year, prompting upgrades today in the Retail division. However there has been less new space opened than we (or the market) had anticipated, so Primark's sales growth in FY Q3 remains only 7% on a constant FX basis (in line with FY H1, but below the 9% figure consensus was expecting for FY Q3). The company has, however, stated that LfLs in the division have improved upon the -1.5% reported in FY H1 (though there is no LfL figure in today's statement).

11:41 am
BE11:41am

The upgrades in the Retail division, however, are going to be offset by further downgrades in Sugar where revenue was down 17% in the quarter, due to weak EU sugar prices.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst how are the markets totally ignoring whats happening at UBS?
BE11:42am

So, consensus forecasts don't change too much though there might be small downgrades to future years due to the sugar headwind. But then, shares are 18.7x Cal 2019.

BE11:43am

(@StandupComedian: because it's massively libelous.)

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst ok fair enough
wayneJ Do my eyes deceive me or has lightening just emanated from BE's finger to frazzle a comment.......
11:43 am
BE11:44am

SocGen as well.

BE11:44am

With FY guidance maintained, we expect little change to FY18 consensus EPS forecasts, although FY19 may come down to reflect the ongoing difficulties in Sugar. But on balance we expect the share price to react well to the changing profits mix and better news on Primark.

StandupComedianTurnedHFAnalyst it did and frazzle is a good word
BE11:44am

Hm. Not so much.

11:44 am
undefined
wayneJ Surely for ABF the consensus should be broken down into a PE for Primark and a PE for sugar.
BE11:45am

(@Standup, WayneJ: alas, the newspaper industry isn't in robust enough shape to wear much legal risk. So, yeah, we zap first and ask questions later.)

wayneJ Different companies find different ways of refocussing their portfolio - some by selling some bits off; others by allowing some bits to constantly warn and shrink
BE11:46am

@Groundhog Day, on Inmarsat: I know nothing. Nothing whatsoever.

wayneJ @BE - I completely understand - was just a gentle tease! (We all appreciate you even tolerate us, the mere unwashed).
Groundhog Day @Be thanks
11:46 am
BE11:46am

Though I left my phone at home this morning, so am a wee bit out of the gossip loop.

wayneJ Is fascinating how Primark continues to grow vs the general gloom on the Highstreet
Groundhog Day Care to speculate on silence from your experience?
BE11:47am

If you've been sending me messages through your preferred messaging platform and haven't had a reply, that'll be why.

Roidster hello all
Roidster Any news on Inmarsat? I cant see them walking away (echostar)...unless they really had no intention of bidding in the first place! hes (ergen) obviously playing his hand of poker?
BE11:49am

(@Groundhog: I'd give you odds of 3/2 on an extension, evens on a bid below 700p and 3/1 on a walk away. All total speculation on my part.)

11:49 am
undefined
Groundhog Day @Be: Thanks - where do I deposit the funds? ;-)
wayneJ Any thoughts on Purple?
BE11:50am

Okay, what else? Purplebricks has been mentioned a few times on the right.

Purplebricks Group PLC (PURP:LSE): Last: 314.73, down 3.87 (-1.21%), High: 315.60, Low: 296.00, Volume: 954.05k
wayneJ And given my favoured attire anything on SuperDry
11:51 am
BE11:51am

The increasingly publicity-hungry branchless gig-economy estate agent thing.

BE11:52am

FY results match guidance, 2019 guidance is a wee bit cautious, investment costs continue to tick higher.

BE11:53am

Headlines are a widening adjusted EBITDA loss of £19.6m on 201% revenue growth to £93.7m.

Tom Dalgleish PURP agents dying on their vine here according to news
wayneJ I am being told that the losses were in line with expectations - I am becoming less convinced this is the case
Roidster @BE just saw your comment re Inmarsat - Many thanks
Tom Dalgleish Not enough referrals forthcoming
wayneJ Also anyone any insight into why the borrow is so tight?
11:54 am
BE11:54am

Group revenue for FY19 guided to £165-185m, so about 85% in the middle, and there's a medium term UK market share target of more than 10%.

BE11:55am

Peel Hunt incoming:

#REF! Estate agents are relatively speaking massively unregulated. Buying a house feels like a constant battle not for someone to rip you off. Not sure Purplebricks helps much with this
BE11:55am

While the current trading backdrop is mixed, Purplebricks continues to invest in its customer offering and technology as it pushes for further market share gains on all frontiers. The new equity from Axel Springer
has facilitated a faster rollout in the US than previously forecast, with an associated increase in marketing spend. Combined with softer near-term market conditions in the UK and Australia, we now expect group profitability in FY21 (previously FY19) and reduce our target price slightly to 440p. Purplebricks remains well placed to deliver significant growth in all of its regions over the next few years and we retain our Buy recommendation.

#REF! *under-regulated I mean. they have a code but they don't stick to it. Renting is bad as well
11:56 am
BE11:56am

That feels slightly throwaway for "profitability's now two years later than we thought before".

hello helo gentle man
BE11:57am

The upshot is that underlying annual increases to marketing spend of 15-30% across the group

GGekko Anything interesting on SDRY?
Tom Dalgleish RE self regulated here by their institute which means complaints are laughed off
BE11:57am

Plus building out the figures for acquisitions.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

So this is what happens to forecasts.

Excel Developer The Only Buyers Of Stock In The First Half Were Buybacks: BofA https://www.zerohedge.com/news/2018-07-04/only-stock-buyers-first-half-were-buybacks-bofa
BE11:57am

The net effect of these changes is an expectation of group losses for FY19 and FY20 and group profitability in FY21 (now PBT of £10m, previously £117m). We previously forecast PBT of £3.8m in FY19 (now a loss of £41.5m). Our target price is based on a blend of EV/Sales and EV/EBITDA multiples for the group’s FY22 financial year (the first year where we forecast a profit contribution from all of the group’s business regions – PBT of c£46m).

Grouchmonkey @Wayne look at the list of shorts on the FCA disclosure list.
BE11:58am

They're shop.

vonB and the Purplebricks brand sounds kinda cheap, not exactly a class act, even in this debased profession
11:58 am
BE11:58am

And of course, when we mention Purplebricks it's the law that we have to quote Anthony Codling.

Pseudonym Where did the "Purple" bit come from?
BE11:59am

Jefferies' analyser of the housing sector and writer of increasingly florid prose.

Pseudonym Just calling it "Bricks" would've sounded better, if harder to google.
BE11:59am

Purplebricks continues to tell us it sells lots of houses, without backing up that rhetoric with actual figures. Sold Subject to Contract does not mean sold. Perhaps more telling is that the number of UK LPEs is now lower than it was six months ago. If the model is the lifeboat for a sinking high street does the lifeboat itself have a leak?

Swedish Chef @von but it’s backed by a ‘star fund manager’
11:59 am
BE12:00pm

At the half year Purplebricks had 650 UK LPEs, at the full year it had 630. It seems odd to us that if Purplebricks really is the lifeboat for a sinking high street why are there fewer people in the boat? Does the lifeboat itself have a leak? Meanwhile EBITDA losses have increased from £4.5m to £19.6m and the Group trades on a CY19E EV/EBITDA of 35x. In our view Purplebricks' model remains unproven and we reiterate our Underperform rating on the shares.

Flaneur Persimmon figs up 5% so 'hooraay' for govt subsidy....
hornblower PURP H2 UK revenue -4% EBITDA -30% sequentially
Soundbuy 'The color purple is often associated with royalty, nobility, luxury, power, and ambition. Purple also represents meanings of wealth, extravagance, creativity, wisdom, dignity, grandeur, devotion, peace, pride, mystery, independence, and magic.'
Tom Dalgleish @REF, PURP does have a production line feel about it
BE12:01pm

(@Pseudonym: slight risk of mishearing. As in, "Who's your house on the market with?" "Bricks." "Yes, all estate agents are.")

Soundbuy Take your pick from the above...............
undefined
wayneJ All the shorts on Purple are small size
Lemmy Soundbuy: fine for purple velvet lining a crown, less so for a hod of bricks?
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

We're overtime but haven't mentioned Superdry.

Soundbuy Small purple shorts?
Superdry PLC (SDRY:LSE): Last: 1,259, up 90 (+7.70%), High: 1,324, Low: 1,235, Volume: 509.06k
wayneJ Purple was associated with the Roman Emperors
#REF! @Tom in my experience agents and conveancers often try for a production line. But its the Tesla production line in a tent ie chaotic and of poor quality focused on volume above all else
BE12:02pm

It's another "cashback = confidence" story.

wayneJ Do I have to confess I have a Purple Hoddie from SuperDry
A. M. @Soundby: "Purple prose is criticized for desaturating the meaning in an author's text by overusing melodramatic and fanciful descriptions"could apply to property descriptions?
Soundbuy :)
12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Post the various warnings and quasi warnings, we have a 25p special.

#REF! @WayneJ Hoddie? Is than a Glen Hoddle themed Hoodie :)
alewis2005 @#REF! a hoodie with strong opinions on the disabled?
Blank canvas thanks for everything today. :)
Baz any chat on the takeover panel and Rangers chairman?
BE12:05pm

Along with a reiteration of FY guidance. I guess the special is the signal that cash can start going back to shareholders rather than being spent on ridiculously huge shops, such as that one in Regent Street.

BE12:06pm

And at, what, 10x or thereabouts, it hasn't been priced for growth for a while.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

Here's RBC.

BE12:07pm

FY18 PBT of £97m in line with guidance range, with gross margin of 58.1% and EBIT margin of 11.5% also in line with our expectations. Special dividend of 25p (paid 14 December) should be well received, and implies one-off cash return to shareholders of £20.5m, on top of ordinary dividend of 31.2p which is in line with our expectations.
Receivables are up 44%, funding wholesale channel expansion, which despite strong inventory year-end position (up 3% year-on-year), has slightly limited cash generation, with year-end net cash position of £76m which is lower than our forecast of £82m.
FY19 guidance unchanged, and looking for high single digit revenue growth (wholesale mid-teens, e-commerce mid-high teens, physical retail challenging) and modest operating margin expansion (20-50bps). US expected to reach break-even in FY19 (vs. £3m loss in FY18), and inventory rebase program still expected to complete by 1H19.
Net, we expect delivery of PBT expectations in FY18, no material change to FY19 guidance and announcement of a special dividend to support the stock in the short term, particularly given significant weakness YTD (down 40%).
SDRY trades on 10x FY19E P/E, at a significant discount to our wider coverage.

BE12:07pm

They're neutral.

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Superdry is facing decelerating traffic and LFL in its physical retail network, partly due to cannibalization effects from wholesale and e-commerce channels in our view, but also potentially from pull forward demand effects from its inventory rebase program in the past two seasons (with one season remaining in Autumn/Winter 2018/19).
The medium-term potential to deliver modest operating margin gains as promised at the September 2018 Capital Markets Day depends on the length and depth of negative physical store LFLs and associated operating delverage, despite higher anticipated growth rates in the higher margin wholesale channel. Net, we forecast 10bps/yr of group EBIT margin expansion to FY22E.
Medium term, the internationalization opportunities that exist in North America and Asia underpinned by the brand’s universal appeal in the casual apparel space are compelling, however given difficult trading conditions (particularly North America), reaching break-even is expected to take until FY20E.

Roidster @BE thanks for your insights today.
undefined
BE12:08pm

@Baz: ha! No.)

12:08 pm
BE12:08pm

Okay, we're done I think.

BE12:09pm

The only thing I forgot to mention was, re Glencore, that the $1bn buyback would seem to suggest that big M&A is off the table for the immediate.

wayneJ @ #REF :-) SuperDry make excellent hoodies
BE12:10pm

Which, if correct, would leave quite a few bag carriers in Bunge.

12:10 pm
BE12:10pm

Ah well.

BE12:10pm

Okay, now we're definitely done. Let's close up and get on with out lives.

BE12:11pm

Ta for joining. Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.
